title: EXTENDED DYNAMIC RANGE IMAGING SYSTEM AND METHOD
abstract: In one embodiment, an imager (201) has an array of photodetectors, each of which accumulates charge during an integration period as a result of light detected during the integration period, the array having a charge capacity which increases during the integration period. A charge capacity controller (202) coupled to the imager (201) adjusts how the imager (201) increases the charge capacity of the array based upon the brightness distribution detected by the imager (201) during at least one previous integration period.

motivations: Conventional imaging systems may struggle to capture scenes with a wide dynamic range of brightness levels, leading to loss of detail in either bright or dark areas.
objectives: Develop an imaging system capable of capturing scenes with an extended dynamic range.
methods: Implement an imager with an array of photodetectors that accumulate charge during an integration period.
Use a charge capacity controller to adjust the charge capacity of the array based on the brightness distribution detected in previous integration periods.
results: Improve the ability to capture scenes with a wide dynamic range of brightness levels, preserving detail in both bright and dark areas.

motivations: Current imaging systems may have limitations in dynamic range, affecting the quality of images captured in varying light conditions.
objectives: Develop an imager with an array of photodetectors that can adjust its charge capacity based on the brightness distribution detected during previous integration periods.
methods: Use an array of photodetectors that accumulate charge during an integration period as a result of detected light.
Implement a charge capacity controller that adjusts how the imager increases the charge capacity of the array based on the brightness distribution detected in previous integration periods.
results: Expected to improve the dynamic range of imaging systems, enhancing image quality in various light conditions.

motivations: Traditional imaging systems have limited dynamic range, making it difficult to capture scenes with both very bright and very dark regions simultaneously.
Fixed charge capacity in photodetector arrays limits the ability to adapt to varying brightness distributions in real-time imaging applications.
objectives: Develop an imaging system with extended dynamic range that can adapt to varying brightness distributions.
Create a method for dynamically adjusting the charge capacity of photodetector arrays based on previous brightness measurements.
methods: Implement an array of photodetectors with variable charge capacity that increases during the integration period.
Use a charge capacity controller that adjusts the charge capacity increase based on brightness distribution from previous integration periods.
results: Enhanced ability to capture high-quality images across a wider range of lighting conditions.
Improved dynamic range performance through adaptive charge capacity control based on scene brightness.
